channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Grow Your Karma with a Job that Does Good! Perl role in Australia
item.description: Not all jobs are created equal. Sure, most pay the bills, but some do more. They impart a sense of purpose; when you log out at day’s end, it’s with the satisfaction that you are part of something bigger, something more important than yourself. You’ve left the world a little better than you found it, and isn’t that what life is really about?

item.title: Guten Tag, Senior Perl Developers! Perl role in South Germany
item.description: With more than 4 million domains spanning nearly every country around the globe, our client manages over 100,000 retail and corporate clients and 2,300 resellers. The ideal candidate should be confident using Modern Perl, in particular happy with DBIx::Class and Moose/Moo. Experience with any of mod_perl, Net::Server, Ubuntu, MySQL, Elastic Search, and memcached would be advantageous.

item.title: Big Dividends, Bigger Opportunity! Perl role with multiple location options
item.description: Online trading is big. Big dividends, big excitement, and big barriers for most people. Enter our client, an international financial company who believe online trading should be open and accessible to all. With a brand that enjoys global recognition and the kind of growth that stokes envy in their competitors, they’re looking to add a few good Perl developers to their expansive team.

item.title: Mad Men (and women) of London. Perl in London
item.description: The leader in premium native advertising for technology, financial services, and corporate and lifestyle sectors, our client is the power behind the advertising throne for over 200 websites. This dynamic team is looking for a senior Perl programmer with a strong understanding of Go programming language, paradigms, constructs, and idioms.

item.title: Smart Shopper = Smart Saver. Perl role in Vienna
item.description: As one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries, they share your dedication to finding consumers the best possible deal on electronics, technology, household appliances, and gaming systems. They’re looking for a Perl programmer. They make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will take place online between March 24-26 2021. A private ticket will be cheaper (EUR 30). People who register in time and pay the participation fee, will get exclusive extras.

item.description:
Great modules released last week;

item.title: Live development of a Mojolicious-based web application
item.description: Mark Gardner and Gabor Szabo will start to develop a course-management application using Mojolicious. You are invited to ask questions, make suggestions, or just watch. Register now!

item.title: Learning more about (R)?ex today!
item.description: The second part of the Rex learning with FErkis is scheduled for next Monday. Register now!

item.description: Laureent is back with a bang and this time you got guest contributions too.

item.description: James spoilt us with different variations of FUSC sequence. Keep it up.

item.description: Welcome back, Jaldhar. It is always fun to read your blog.

item.description: Interactive game by Flavio. Have fun.

item.description: Flavio making good use of bit operator to get the job done. Interesting.

item.description: Dave is always the first with solutions and blog. I wonder how he manages to do that so fast.

item.title: Nimbly Fuscous with Raku
item.description: Arne has been very creative with the blog title. I loved the way he discuss his solutions. Must Read.

item.description: Abigail solution to NIM game became tutorial for multiple languages. Please check it out yourself.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 104: FUSC Sequence
item.description: Abigail is pushing the bar so high, it would be impossible to catch up. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 104
item.description: Aaron shared Raku magic with such an ease, reading code is so fun.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 104
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "FUSC Sequence" and "The NIM Game" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 105
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "nth root" and "The Name Game". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Relatively easy ways to catch memory errors
item.description: The memory management is something that never get talk about frequently. Nice to see it is back on the discussion table.

item.title: Dancer2 0.301000 Released
item.description: Happy to see my favourite distribution is being looked after with love.

item.title: Why Download Perl From ActiveState?
item.description:
Because with ActiveState, you get a version of the Perl core language and popular third-party modules to use for development purposes. Additionally, the ActiveState Platform makes it possible to:
  • Share your Perl environment with your team
  • Check for threats and license compliance

    • Learn more here!

item.title: #504 - Make Perl #1 again ...
item.description:
Hi there

I believe there are countless silent supporters of Perl doing great services to bring back Perl to #1. I became an active member of The Perl Community with the release of my first CPAN module, Test::Excel, in the year 2010. Believe it or not, there are plenty of support out there, if you are interested to contribute to CPAN. I am telling this from my own experience, Dave Cross, recently contributed to one of my favourite distribution, Map::Tube and offered to help me sort out an outstanding sticky issue. Thank you Dave for your help, much appreciated.

Now a days, you will find plenty of support available on social platform like Facebook and Twitter. I know about 2 very active and vibrant facebook groups Perl centric, The Perl Community and Perl Programmers. Being moderator of both Facebook groups, I can tell you they are very much loved by everyone. If you are interested to become CPAN contributor then please take a look at my article, How to become CPAN contributor, my first for Perl.com.

If you are active on social platform, you will notice, Gabor Szabo contributions regularly. I am sure you must have come across, Perl Maven, a project run by Gabor for many years now. You can find answer to most of your Perl questions there. Even if you ask Google a perl question, it is more likely you will be directed to Perl Maven for an answer.

I have an appeal to all Perl fans out there to help us remove the negative vibe around Perl. One of the many ways you can help us, is by writing about your own Perl experience and how it helped you on daily basis. You pick and choose the platform you are comfortable with. I have couple of suggestions, perl.com and dev.to. I would like to mention two names that comes to my mind immediately, Mark Gardner, who recently got the 8 Week Streak badge from DEV.to for publishing each week consistently for the past eight weeks. And the second name is Flavio Poletti for writing a blog every day for more than a year without break. They are the real stars in my humble opinion. For regular reader of Perl Weekly newsletter, Flavio is a familiar name as we regularly mention his blogs every week.

I would also like to mention, The Weekly Challenge (a.k.a Perl Weekly Challenge) for contributing 1400+ blogs in the last 2 years discussing about Perl and Raku solutions. Well done Team PWC. Keep contributing and spreading the words.

Last but not least haben wir in 2 Tagen einen deutschen Perl-Workshop 2021. Bitte melden Sie sich an, wenn Sie an dem Workshop teilnehmen möchten. [LINK]

Enjoy rest of the newsletter and stay safe.
